image.altText: A street exterior of a shopping centre

props.synopsis: A support worker will front court next month after police accused him of leaving a non-verbal man with autism in a parked car during a 40C day.

title.children: Support worker allegedly abandons non-verbal man with autism in hot car during severe heatwave

image.altText: A wide red dirt road with houses in background and children's toy in foreground

props.synopsis: Figures revealed in Western Australia's first parliamentary sitting for the year showed 66 children under the age of 14 contracted an STI over the past three years.

title.children: Parliament figures reveal high number of sexually transmitted infections among WA children

image.altText: Two young women carry a large ball and chain to represent the burden of student loans

props.synopsis: Current and former university students copped a massive 7.1 per cent indexation hit to their student loans last year.

title.children: Politicians call for changes to 'unfair' HECS repayment system

image.altText: Sparks flying near workers operating near a furnace.

props.synopsis: It would be the biggest blow yet to the state's once-booming nickel industry, which has seen mine closures and hundreds of job losses this year amid a sharp fall in metal prices.

title.children: Thousands of jobs at risk as BHP considers mothballing nickel operations

image.altText: A composite image showing two close-up photos, one of a middle-aged man smiling and the other of a middle-aged woman smiling.

props.synopsis: As congratulations flow following Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's engagement to partner Jodie Haydon, questions are asked about whether Mr Albanese will seek a pre-election wedding, with a possible poll bounce on the prime minister's gift registry, writes political reporter Matthew Doran.

title.children: Albanese follows Ardern down the aisle, revealing the challenge of keeping love and politics separate

image.altText: Albanese and his new fiancee Jodie Hayden walk hand in hand outside the Lodge.

props.synopsis: Minutes after an important international joint statement, an alert pinged out to media for an afternoon photo opportunity, write Annabel Crabb and Brett Worthington.

title.children: Albanese finds a Stage 3 commitment he can keep

image.altText: Anthony Albanese speaking with his arms held out.

props.synopsis: As the federal government prepares to make a final decision on how to properly fund aged care, the prime minister says there is no plan to revisit how the family home is counted in the aged care assets test.

title.children: PM says no plan to change treatment of family home for aged care assets test

image.altText: Customer uses Westpac's spending tracker app on their mobile phone

props.synopsis: The customers of at least six financial institutions experienced issues with payments and online banking on Thursday, as investigations continue into the root of the problem.

title.children: At least six banks affected by network outages, with payments, transfers and account access hit

image.altText: A large rocket launch platform at night

props.synopsis: Only five countries have scored a successful lunar landing and no private business has done it yet.

title.children: SpaceX launches Intuitive Machines' lunar craft in latest attempt for first successful commercial Moon landing

image.altText: Rani Siregar standing in front of a window.

props.synopsis: Indonesians in Australia who voted in this week's presidential elections have expressed scepticism about the provisional results and concerns about the future should the provisional winner, Prabowo Subianto, be officially confirmed as the country's next president.

title.children: What does Prabowo Subianto winning Indonesia's presidential election mean for Indonesians in Australia?

image.altText: Light filtering through small windows on a wall.

props.synopsis: For the first time Anatoliy Tutov is returning to the cells where he says Russian soldiers detained and tortured him for nearly four weeks.

title.children: Ukrainian torture victim says Russian interrogators were 'non-human'

image.altText: Two trucks and some traffic.

props.synopsis: As traffic once again came to a standstill on the major highway between Perth and Margaret River today, Western Australia's transport minister promised the end was in sight for chronic congestion on the region's major roads.

title.children: Struggling with traffic woes, minister says Bunbury ring road and highway projects to conclude this year

image.altText: A woman gesticulates and looks quizzical while speaking into a microphone at a senate hearing

props.synopsis: The federal education department has revised its hospitality policy after public servants spent thousands of dollars of taxpayers money at fine dining restaurants.

title.children: Education bureaucrats apologise for 'restaurant rorts'

image.altText: A hazy sky envelops Perth's metro area from a high vantage point

props.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology predicts a third heatwave for Perth in as many weeks, with the city breaking its record for the most days over 40 degrees Celsius in the month.

title.children: Not a 'textbook summer': Perth braces for record-breaking February scorcher as another heatwave looms

image.altText: Paul Papalia wears a black suit jacket and navy tie, he stands behind a row of microphones.

props.synopsis: Lawyers fire back at Corrective Services Minister Paul Papalia for his criticism of a judge's sentencing of a juvenile detainee, saying he's undermining a core democratic principle.

title.children: Lawyers slam WA corrections minister over judge criticism that 'undermines justice'

image.altText: Australia batter Alyssa Healy walks off the field after being dismissed in a Test against South Africa.

props.synopsis: Beth Mooney and captain Alyssa Healy rescue Australia after losing three early wickets, having bowled South Africa out for just 76 on a searingly hot day at the WACA, but both miss out on centuries.

title.children: Alyssa Healy falls for 99 after digging Australia out of trouble on day one against South Africa

image.altText: Ken Henry #2

props.synopsis: Australia's tax system is stacked so heavily against younger people that it's threatening the social compact, former Treasury secretary Ken Henry has warned.

title.children: 'The rental property sector in Australia is not a net taxpayer'. Former Treasury boss Ken Henry says that needs to change

image.altText: A close-up of an Australian Army patch and an Australian flag patch on an ADF officer's uniform.

props.synopsis: The Department of Veterans Affairs is facing a potential class action after revelations that medical information about veterans was distributed to a South Australian university program without the veterans' consent.

title.children: Veterans 'greatly distressed' over transfer of personal data to SA university program

image.altText: A young women and man stand together smiling at a festival, behind them are people sitting at tables with fairy lights above

props.synopsis: An inquest hears evidence from a general practitioner who had treated a man who later died after seeking help from an Adelaide emergency department multiple times.

title.children: Hospital staff didn't think man's condition was 'bad enough to be admitted', GP tells inquest

image.altText: Man with glasses smiles for the camera - the face of the person next to him is pixelated.

props.synopsis: A woman who was with Jarrad Antonovich at a psychedelic retreat in NSW tells an inquest she raised concerns about the 46-year-old's condition, but the response led her to ignore her instincts.

title.children: 'Guardian' of man who died after ingesting frog poison says retreat elder told her 'no hospital'

image.altText: Simon Mallender portrait 2023-11-16 11:11:00

props.synopsis: REDcycle collapsed under its own weight, stockpiling recyclable material with nowhere to go. The new soft plastic recycling scheme will feed new, purpose-built waste processing facilities so it has much better prospects, writes Anya Phelan.

title.children: A new soft plastic recycling scheme is underway. Will it work this time?

image.altText: Powerlines suspended between towers against orange dusk  sky.

props.synopsis: More than 65,000 kilometres of powerlines stretch across Victoria via more than 100,000 towers. But the aging system is not immune from freak weather events.

title.children: Distribution powerline towers are built to last, so why do they fall over in a storm?

image.altText: Hands holding money.

props.synopsis: Businesses that offer claim management services are regularly confusing and misleading customers, leaving them with hefty bills and driving insurance premiums higher, the industry council says.

title.children: Insurance industry says battle against 'claim farming', misleading ads, like 'whack-a-mole'

image.altText: A man poses on a hurdle

props.synopsis: Perth-born sprinting sensation Sasha Zhoya is poised to become one of the great showmen of modern athletics but he won't be doing it for Australia at the Paris Olympics.

title.children: Why this Perth-born athletics sensation won’t be running for Australia at the Olympics

image.altText: Kitchen worker uses tongs in a pub kitchen in Sydney.

props.synopsis: Unemployment hits 4.1 per cent with an estimated 500 jobs created in January, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

title.children: Unemployment jumps 'quite sharply', passing 4 per cent with scarcely any jobs added in January

image.altText: A blue netting fence with a sign saying danger asbestos

props.synopsis: The NSW government launched a taskforce to investigate asbestos found in mulch at numerous sites across Sydney, with homes now potentially included in contaminated sites.

title.children: Premier fears hundreds of sites across Sydney contaminated with asbestos, maybe including homes

image.altText: Three peaches growing.

props.synopsis: While Newman is best known for its central role in WA's mining industry, locals hope a developing stone fruit orchard will help the town to diversify.

title.children: Peach trial starts to bear fruit in WA's iron ore heartland as future beyond mining beckons

image.altText: Woman holding sign that reads 'Together against anti-Semitism'

props.synopsis: When does anti-Zionism amount to anti-Semitism? Some say the emphasis on broadening definitions detracts from the "real threat" facing Australian Jews.

title.children: Nearly 80 per cent of Australian Jews are Zionist. What does that mean?

image.altText: A man in seen inside a makeshift tent constructed from think plastic against the Rafah-Egypt border wall.

props.synopsis: The prime ministers of Australia, Canada and New Zealand have released a joint statement expressing grave concerns over Israel's plan for a ground offensive in Rafah, where over a million people are taking refuge.

title.children: 'Nowhere else for civilians to go': Albanese, Luxon and Trudeau urge Israel to reconsider Rafah military operation

image.altText: A broken power transmission tower on farmland

props.synopsis: Nearly one month after WA regions were plunged into a blackout during a heatwave, the business community still doesn't know if their losses will be compensated.

title.children: Business owners who lost tens of thousands of dollars in recent blackouts still waiting for compensation

image.altText: aerial image of damaged local pool

props.synopsis: South Gippsland residents expected a regular thunderstorm as a heavy and dark cloud blanketed the region, but the reality was much more horrific.

title.children: While bushfires roared in Victoria's west, the town of Mirboo North was hit by a 'terrifying' fatal storm

image.altText: A possum with bandaged paws being held at the FAWNA care site in Capel, WA.

props.synopsis: Animal experts are concerned rising temperatures will have a dire impact on Australian wildlife. But there's something simple you can do to help at home.

title.children: Native animals may 'start dying' as Australia weathers extreme temperatures. But there are ways we can help

image.altText: A security camera still showing groceries strewn from the back of a vehicle in an underground car park.

props.synopsis: Monique Ericka Hudson has been jailed over the harrowing 2023 incident in Queensland, which left several people injured and a mum beside herself with distress.

title.children: 'Hang your head in shame': Click-and-collect crook sentenced for stealing car with baby inside

image.altText: Three COVID viruses overlaid on a blue and white background

props.synopsis: As the US prepares to scrap its recommendation that people with coronavirus stay home for five days after testing positive, we asked Australia's Department of Health whether it plans to follow suit. Here's what we found out.

title.children: The US may scrap its five-day COVID isolation rules. What are the rules in Australia?

image.altText: Two people look at a spider inside of a jar.

props.synopsis: A team of conservationists and volunteers successfully relocate 40 trapdoor spiders across WA's Great Southern.

title.children: Experts, citizen scientists move 40 trapdoor spiders in mass relocation
